    6288             : /*
    6289             :  * Display a sort/group clause.
    6290             :  *
    6291             :  * Also returns the expression tree, so caller need not find it again.
    6292             :  */
    6293             : static Node *
    6294         570 : get_rule_sortgroupclause(Index ref, List *tlist, bool force_colno,
    6295             :                          deparse_context *context)
    6296             : {
    6297         570 :     StringInfo  buf = context->buf;
    6298             :     TargetEntry *tle;
    6299             :     Node       *expr;
    6300             : 
    6301         570 :     tle = get_sortgroupref_tle(ref, tlist);
    6302         570 :     expr = (Node *) tle->expr;
    6303             : 
    6304             :     /*
    6305             :      * Use column-number form if requested by caller.  Otherwise, if
    6306             :      * expression is a constant, force it to be dumped with an explicit cast
    6307             :      * as decoration --- this is because a simple integer constant is
    6308             :      * ambiguous (and will be misinterpreted by findTargetlistEntry()) if we
    6309             :      * dump it without any decoration.  If it's anything more complex than a
    6310             :      * simple Var, then force extra parens around it, to ensure it can't be
    6311             :      * misinterpreted as a cube() or rollup() construct.
    6312             :      */
    6313         570 :     if (force_colno)
    6314             :     {
    6315           0 :         Assert(!tle->resjunk);
    6316           0 :         appendStringInfo(buf, "%d", tle->resno);
    6317             :     }
    6318         570 :     else if (expr && IsA(expr, Const))
    6319           0 :         get_const_expr((Const *) expr, context, 1);
    6320         570 :     else if (!expr || IsA(expr, Var))
    6321         542 :         get_rule_expr(expr, context, true);
    6322             :     else
    6323             :     {
    6324             :         /*
    6325             :          * We must force parens for function-like expressions even if
    6326             :          * PRETTY_PAREN is off, since those are the ones in danger of
    6327             :          * misparsing. For other expressions we need to force them only if
    6328             :          * PRETTY_PAREN is on, since otherwise the expression will output them
    6329             :          * itself. (We can't skip the parens.)
    6330             :          */
    6331          56 :         bool        need_paren = (PRETTY_PAREN(context)
    6332          28 :                                   || IsA(expr, FuncExpr)
    6333          24 :                                   || IsA(expr, Aggref)
    6334          24 :                                   || IsA(expr, WindowFunc)
    6335          56 :                                   || IsA(expr, JsonConstructorExpr));
    6336             : 
    6337          28 :         if (need_paren)
    6338           4 :             appendStringInfoChar(context->buf, '(');
    6339          28 :         get_rule_expr(expr, context, true);
    6340          28 :         if (need_paren)
    6341           4 :             appendStringInfoChar(context->buf, ')');
    6342             :     }
    6343             : 
    6344         570 :     return expr;

    6497             : /*

    7234             : 
    7235             : /*
    7236             :  * Display a Var appropriately.
    7237             :  *
    7238             :  * In some cases (currently only when recursing into an unnamed join)
    7239             :  * the Var's varlevelsup has to be interpreted with respect to a context
    7240             :  * above the current one; levelsup indicates the offset.
    7241             :  *
    7242             :  * If istoplevel is true, the Var is at the top level of a SELECT's
    7243             :  * targetlist, which means we need special treatment of whole-row Vars.
    7244             :  * Instead of the normal "tab.*", we'll print "tab.*::typename", which is a
    7245             :  * dirty hack to prevent "tab.*" from being expanded into multiple columns.
    7246             :  * (The parser will strip the useless coercion, so no inefficiency is added in
    7247             :  * dump and reload.)  We used to print just "tab" in such cases, but that is
    7248             :  * ambiguous and will yield the wrong result if "tab" is also a plain column
    7249             :  * name in the query.
    7250             :  *
    7251             :  * Returns the attname of the Var, or NULL if the Var has no attname (because
    7252             :  * it is a whole-row Var or a subplan output reference).
    7253             :  */
    7254             : static char *
    7255      141268 : get_variable(Var *var, int levelsup, bool istoplevel, deparse_context *context)
    7256             : {
    7257      141268 :     StringInfo  buf = context->buf;
    7258             :     RangeTblEntry *rte;
    7259             :     AttrNumber  attnum;
    7260             :     int         netlevelsup;
    7261             :     deparse_namespace *dpns;
    7262             :     int         varno;
    7263             :     AttrNumber  varattno;
    7264             :     deparse_columns *colinfo;
    7265             :     char       *refname;
    7266             :     char       *attname;
    7267             : 
    7268             :     /* Find appropriate nesting depth */
    7269      141268 :     netlevelsup = var->varlevelsup + levelsup;
    7270      141268 :     if (netlevelsup >= list_length(context->namespaces))
    7271           0 :         elog(ERROR, "bogus varlevelsup: %d offset %d",
    7272             :              var->varlevelsup, levelsup);
    7273      141268 :     dpns = (deparse_namespace *) list_nth(context->namespaces,
    7274             :                                           netlevelsup);
    7275             : 
    7276             :     /*
    7277             :      * If we have a syntactic referent for the Var, and we're working from a
    7278             :      * parse tree, prefer to use the syntactic referent.  Otherwise, fall back
    7279             :      * on the semantic referent.  (Forcing use of the semantic referent when
    7280             :      * printing plan trees is a design choice that's perhaps more motivated by
    7281             :      * backwards compatibility than anything else.  But it does have the
    7282             :      * advantage of making plans more explicit.)
    7283             :      */
    7284      141268 :     if (var->varnosyn > 0 && dpns->plan == NULL)
    7285             :     {
    7286       28364 :         varno = var->varnosyn;
    7287       28364 :         varattno = var->varattnosyn;

    7289             :     else
    7290             :     {

    7292      112904 :         varattno = var->varattno;
    7293             :     }
    7294             :

    7358             : 
    7359             :     /*
    7360             :      * The planner will sometimes emit Vars referencing resjunk elements of a
    7361             :      * subquery's target list (this is currently only possible if it chooses
    7362             :      * to generate a "physical tlist" for a SubqueryScan or CteScan node).
    7363             :      * Although we prefer to print subquery-referencing Vars using the
    7364             :      * subquery's alias, that's not possible for resjunk items since they have
    7365             :      * no alias.  So in that case, drill down to the subplan and print the
    7366             :      * contents of the referenced tlist item.  This works because in a plan
    7367             :      * tree, such Vars can only occur in a SubqueryScan or CteScan node, and
    7368             :      * we'll have set dpns->inner_plan to reference the child plan node.
    7369             :      */

    7372           2 :         dpns->inner_plan)
    7373             :     {
    7374             :         TargetEntry *tle;

    7376             : 
    7377           2 :         tle = get_tle_by_resno(dpns->inner_tlist, attnum);

    7394             : 
    7395           2 :         pop_child_plan(dpns, &save_dpns);
    7396           2 :         return NULL;
    7397             :     }
    7398             : 
    7399             :     /*
    7400             :      * If it's an unnamed join, look at the expansion of the alias variable.
    7401             :      * If it's a simple reference to one of the input vars, then recursively
    7402             :      * print the name of that var instead.  When it's not a simple reference,
    7403             :      * we have to just print the unqualified join column name.  (This can only
    7404             :      * happen with "dangerous" merged columns in a JOIN USING; we took pains
    7405             :      * previously to make the unqualified column name unique in such cases.)
    7406             :      *
    7407             :      * This wouldn't work in decompiling plan trees, because we don't store
    7408             :      * joinaliasvars lists after planning; but a plan tree should never
    7409             :      * contain a join alias variable.
    7410             :      */

    7427             :

    7434             :     }

    7446             :         /*

    7480             : 
    7481             : /*
    7482             :  * Deparse a Var which references OUTER_VAR, INNER_VAR, or INDEX_VAR.  This
    7483             :  * routine is actually a callback for resolve_special_varno, which handles
    7484             :  * finding the correct TargetEntry.  We get the expression contained in that
    7485             :  * TargetEntry and just need to deparse it, a job we can throw back on
    7486             :  * get_rule_expr.
    7487             :  */
    7488             : static void
    7489       35438 : get_special_variable(Node *node, deparse_context *context, void *callback_arg)
    7490             : {
    7491       35438 :     StringInfo  buf = context->buf;
    7492             : 
    7493             :     /*
    7494             :      * For a non-Var referent, force parentheses because our caller probably
    7495             :      * assumed a Var is a simple expression.
    7496             :      */

    7500       35438 :     if (!IsA(node, Var))

    7502       35438 : }
    7503             : 
    7504             : /*
    7505             :  * Chase through plan references to special varnos (OUTER_VAR, INNER_VAR,
    7506             :  * INDEX_VAR) until we find a real Var or some kind of non-Var node; then,

    7599             : 
    7600             : /*
    7601             :  * Get the name of a field of an expression of composite type.  The
    7602             :  * expression is usually a Var, but we handle other cases too.
    7603             :  *
    7604             :  * levelsup is an extra offset to interpret the Var's varlevelsup correctly.
    7605             :  *
    7606             :  * This is fairly straightforward when the expression has a named composite
    7607             :  * type; we need only look up the type in the catalogs.  However, the type
    7608             :  * could also be RECORD.  Since no actual table or view column is allowed to
    7609             :  * have type RECORD, a Var of type RECORD must refer to a JOIN or FUNCTION RTE
    7610             :  * or to a subquery output.  We drill down to find the ultimate defining
    7611             :  * expression and attempt to infer the field name from it.  We ereport if we
    7612             :  * can't determine the name.
    7613             :  *
    7614             :  * Similarly, a PARAM of type RECORD has to refer to some expression of
    7615             :  * a determinable composite type.
    7616             :  */
    7617             : static const char *
    7618         958 : get_name_for_var_field(Var *var, int fieldno,
    7619             :                        int levelsup, deparse_context *context)
    7620             : {
    7621             :     RangeTblEntry *rte;
    7622             :     AttrNumber  attnum;
    7623             :     int         netlevelsup;
    7624             :     deparse_namespace *dpns;
    7625             :     int         varno;
    7626             :     AttrNumber  varattno;
    7627             :     TupleDesc   tupleDesc;
    7628             :     Node       *expr;
    7629             : 
    7630             :     /*
    7631             :      * If it's a RowExpr that was expanded from a whole-row Var, use the
    7632             :      * column names attached to it.  (We could let get_expr_result_tupdesc()
    7633             :      * handle this, but it's much cheaper to just pull out the name we need.)
    7634             :      */
    7635         958 :     if (IsA(var, RowExpr))
    7636             :     {
    7637          36 :         RowExpr    *r = (RowExpr *) var;
    7638             : 
    7639          36 :         if (fieldno > 0 && fieldno <= list_length(r->colnames))
    7640          36 :             return strVal(list_nth(r->colnames, fieldno - 1));
    7641             :     }
    7642             : 
    7643             :     /*
    7644             :      * If it's a Param of type RECORD, try to find what the Param refers to.
    7645             :      */
    7646         922 :     if (IsA(var, Param))
    7647             :     {
    7648          18 :         Param      *param = (Param *) var;
    7649             :         ListCell   *ancestor_cell;
    7650             : 
    7651          18 :         expr = find_param_referent(param, context, &dpns, &ancestor_cell);
    7652          18 :         if (expr)
    7653             :         {
    7654             :             /* Found a match, so recurse to decipher the field name */
    7655             :             deparse_namespace save_dpns;
    7656             :             const char *result;
    7657             : 
    7658          18 :             push_ancestor_plan(dpns, ancestor_cell, &save_dpns);
    7659          18 :             result = get_name_for_var_field((Var *) expr, fieldno,
    7660             :                                             0, context);
    7661          18 :             pop_ancestor_plan(dpns, &save_dpns);
    7662          18 :             return result;
    7663             :         }
    7664             :     }
    7665             : 
    7666             :     /*
    7667             :      * If it's a Var of type RECORD, we have to find what the Var refers to;
    7668             :      * if not, we can use get_expr_result_tupdesc().
    7669             :      */

    7671         842 :         var->vartype != RECORDOID)
    7672             :     {
    7673         694 :         tupleDesc = get_expr_result_tupdesc((Node *) var, false);
    7674             :         /* Got the tupdesc, so we can extract the field name */
    7675         694 :         Assert(fieldno >= 1 && fieldno <= tupleDesc->natts);
    7676         694 :         return NameStr(TupleDescAttr(tupleDesc, fieldno - 1)->attname);
    7677             :     }
    7678             : 
    7679             :     /* Find appropriate nesting depth */

    7684         210 :     dpns = (deparse_namespace *) list_nth(context->namespaces,
    7685             :                                           netlevelsup);
    7686             : 
    7687             :     /*
    7688             :      * If we have a syntactic referent for the Var, and we're working from a
    7689             :      * parse tree, prefer to use the syntactic referent.  Otherwise, fall back
    7690             :      * on the semantic referent.  (See comments in get_variable().)

    7975             :                      * referencing a CTE RTE are in CteScan or WorkTableScan
    7976             :                      * plan nodes.  For those cases, set_deparse_plan arranged
    7977             :                      * for dpns->inner_plan to be the plan node that emits the

    7979             :                      * tlist instead.
    7980             :                      */
    7981             :                     TargetEntry *tle;
    7982             :                     deparse_namespace save_dpns;
    7983             :                     const char *result;
    7984             : 
    7985          30 :                     if (!dpns->inner_plan)
    7986           0 :                         elog(ERROR, "failed to find plan for CTE %s",
    7987             :                              rte->eref->aliasname);
    7988          30 :                     tle = get_tle_by_resno(dpns->inner_tlist, attnum);
    7989          30 :                     if (!tle)
    7990           0 :                         elog(ERROR, "bogus varattno for subquery var: %d",
    7991             :                              attnum);
    7992          30 :                     Assert(netlevelsup == 0);
    7993          30 :                     push_child_plan(dpns, dpns->inner_plan, &save_dpns);

    7998          30 :                     pop_child_plan(dpns, &save_dpns);
    7999          30 :                     return result;

    8001             :             }
    8002          12 :             break;

    8014             : 
    8015             : /*
    8016             :  * Try to find the referenced expression for a PARAM_EXEC Param that might
    8017             :  * reference a parameter supplied by an upper NestLoop or SubPlan plan node.
    8018             :  *
    8019             :  * If successful, return the expression and set *dpns_p and *ancestor_cell_p
    8020             :  * appropriately for calling push_ancestor_plan().  If no referent can be
    8021             :  * found, return NULL.
    8022             :  */
    8023             : static Node *
    8024        5400 : find_param_referent(Param *param, deparse_context *context,
    8025             :                     deparse_namespace **dpns_p, ListCell **ancestor_cell_p)
    8026             : {
    8027             :     /* Initialize output parameters to prevent compiler warnings */
    8028        5400 :     *dpns_p = NULL;
    8029        5400 :     *ancestor_cell_p = NULL;
    8030             : 
    8031             :     /*
    8032             :      * If it's a PARAM_EXEC parameter, look for a matching NestLoopParam or
    8033             :      * SubPlan argument.  This will necessarily be in some ancestor of the
    8034             :      * current expression's Plan node.
    8035             :      */
    8036        5400 :     if (param->paramkind == PARAM_EXEC)
    8037             :     {
    8038             :         deparse_namespace *dpns;
    8039             :         Plan       *child_plan;
    8040             :         ListCell   *lc;
    8041             : 
    8042        4540 :         dpns = (deparse_namespace *) linitial(context->namespaces);
    8043        4540 :         child_plan = dpns->plan;
    8044             : 
    8045        8328 :         foreach(lc, dpns->ancestors)
    8046             :         {
    8047        6992 :             Node       *ancestor = (Node *) lfirst(lc);
    8048             :             ListCell   *lc2;
    8049             : 
    8050             :             /*
    8051             :              * NestLoops transmit params to their inner child only.
    8052             :              */
    8053        6992 :             if (IsA(ancestor, NestLoop) &&
    8054        2964 :                 child_plan == innerPlan(ancestor))
    8055             :             {
    8056        2872 :                 NestLoop   *nl = (NestLoop *) ancestor;
    8057             : 
    8058        3414 :                 foreach(lc2, nl->nestParams)

    8063             :                     {

    8072             :             /*

    8121             :             /* No luck, crawl up to next ancestor */

    8125             :

    8266             : /*
    8267             :  * isSimpleNode - check if given node is simple (doesn't need parenthesizing)
    8268             :  *
    8269             :  *  true   : simple in the context of parent node's type
    8270             :  *  false  : not simple
    8271             :  */
    8272             : static bool
    8273        4616 : isSimpleNode(Node *node, Node *parentNode, int prettyFlags)

    8491             : 
    8492             : /*
    8493             :  * appendContextKeyword - append a keyword to buffer
    8494             :  *
    8495             :  * If prettyPrint is enabled, perform a line break, and adjust indentation.
    8496             :  * Otherwise, just append the keyword.
    8497             :  */
    8498             : static void
    8499       20966 : appendContextKeyword(deparse_context *context, const char *str,
    8500             :                      int indentBefore, int indentAfter, int indentPlus)
    8501             : {
    8502       20966 :     StringInfo  buf = context->buf;
    8503             : 
    8504       20966 :     if (PRETTY_INDENT(context))
    8505             :     {
    8506             :         int         indentAmount;
    8507             : 
    8508       20668 :         context->indentLevel += indentBefore;
    8509             : 
    8510             :         /* remove any trailing spaces currently in the buffer ... */
    8511       20668 :         removeStringInfoSpaces(buf);
    8512             :         /* ... then add a newline and some spaces */
    8513       20668 :         appendStringInfoChar(buf, '\n');
    8514             : 
    8515       20668 :         if (context->indentLevel < PRETTYINDENT_LIMIT)
    8516       20668 :             indentAmount = Max(context->indentLevel, 0) + indentPlus;
    8517             :         else
    8518             :         {
    8519             :             /*
    8520             :              * If we're indented more than PRETTYINDENT_LIMIT characters, try
    8521             :              * to conserve horizontal space by reducing the per-level
    8522             :              * indentation.  For best results the scale factor here should
    8523             :              * divide all the indent amounts that get added to indentLevel
    8524             :              * (PRETTYINDENT_STD, etc).  It's important that the indentation
    8525             :              * not grow unboundedly, else deeply-nested trees use O(N^2)
    8526             :              * whitespace; so we also wrap modulo PRETTYINDENT_LIMIT.
    8527             :              */
    8528           0 :             indentAmount = PRETTYINDENT_LIMIT +
    8529           0 :                 (context->indentLevel - PRETTYINDENT_LIMIT) /
    8530             :                 (PRETTYINDENT_STD / 2);
    8531           0 :             indentAmount %= PRETTYINDENT_LIMIT;
    8532             :             /* scale/wrap logic affects indentLevel, but not indentPlus */
    8533           0 :             indentAmount += indentPlus;
    8534             :         }
    8535       20668 :         appendStringInfoSpaces(buf, indentAmount);
    8536             : 
    8537       20668 :         appendStringInfoString(buf, str);
    8538             : 
    8539       20668 :         context->indentLevel += indentAfter;
    8540       20668 :         if (context->indentLevel < 0)
    8541           0 :             context->indentLevel = 0;
    8542             :     }
    8543             :     else
    8544         298 :         appendStringInfoString(buf, str);
    8545       20966 : }
    8546             : 
    8547             : /*
    8548             :  * removeStringInfoSpaces - delete trailing spaces from a buffer.
    8549             :  *
    8550             :  * Possibly this should move to stringinfo.c at some point.
    8551             :  */

    8558             : 
    8559             : 
    8560             : /*
    8561             :  * get_rule_expr_paren  - deparse expr using get_rule_expr,
    8562             :  * embracing the string with parentheses if necessary for prettyPrint.
    8563             :  *
    8564             :  * Never embrace if prettyFlags=0, because it's done in the calling node.
    8565             :  *
    8566             :  * Any node that does *not* embrace its argument node by sql syntax (with
    8567             :  * parentheses, non-operator keywords like CASE/WHEN/ON, or comma etc) should
    8568             :  * use get_rule_expr_paren instead of get_rule_expr so parentheses can be

    8571             : static void
    8572      140092 : get_rule_expr_paren(Node *node, deparse_context *context,

    8582             :

    8584             : 
    8585      140092 :     if (need_paren)
    8586         108 :         appendStringInfoChar(context->buf, ')');

    8588             : 
    8589             : 
    8590             : /* ----------
    8591             :  * get_rule_expr            - Parse back an expression
    8592             :  *
    8593             :  * Note: showimplicit determines whether we display any implicit cast that
    8594             :  * is present at the top of the expression tree.  It is a passed argument,
    8595             :  * not a field of the context struct, because we change the value as we
    8596             :  * recurse down into the expression.  In general we suppress implicit casts
    8597             :  * when the result type is known with certainty (eg, the arguments of an
    8598             :  * OR must be boolean).  We display implicit casts for arguments of functions
    8599             :  * and operators, since this is needed to be certain that the same function
    8600             :  * or operator will be chosen when the expression is re-parsed.
    8601             :  * ----------
    8602             :  */
    8603             : static void
    8604      281120 : get_rule_expr(Node *node, deparse_context *context,
    8605             :               bool showimplicit)
    8606             : {
    8607      281120 :     StringInfo  buf = context->buf;
    8608             : 
    8609      281120 :     if (node == NULL)
    8610          96 :         return;
    8611             : 
    8612             :     /* Guard against excessively long or deeply-nested queries */
    8613      281024 :     CHECK_FOR_INTERRUPTS();
    8614      281024 :     check_stack_depth();
    8615             : 
    8616             :     /*
    8617             :      * Each level of get_rule_expr must emit an indivisible term
    8618             :      * (parenthesized if necessary) to ensure result is reparsed into the same
    8619             :      * expression tree.  The only exception is that when the input is a List,
    8620             :      * we emit the component items comma-separated with no surrounding
    8621             :      * decoration; this is convenient for most callers.

    8788             :                  * SubLink.  To prevent misparsing the output that way, insert

    8938             : 
    8939           6 :         case T_FieldStore:
    8940             :             {
    8941           6 :                 FieldStore *fstore = (FieldStore *) node;
    8942             :                 bool        need_parens;
    8943             : 
    8944             :                 /*
    8945             :                  * There is no good way to represent a FieldStore as real SQL,
    8946             :                  * so decompilation of INSERT or UPDATE statements should
    8947             :                  * always use processIndirection as part of the
    8948             :                  * statement-level syntax.  We should only get here when
    8949             :                  * EXPLAIN tries to print the targetlist of a plan resulting
    8950             :                  * from such a statement.  The plan case is even harder than
    8951             :                  * ordinary rules would be, because the planner tries to
    8952             :                  * collapse multiple assignments to the same field or subfield
    8953             :                  * into one FieldStore; so we can see a list of target fields
    8954             :                  * not just one, and the arguments could be FieldStores
    8955             :                  * themselves.  We don't bother to try to print the target
    8956             :                  * field names; we just print the source arguments, with a
    8957             :                  * ROW() around them if there's more than one.  This isn't
    8958             :                  * terribly complete, but it's probably good enough for
    8959             :                  * EXPLAIN's purposes; especially since anything more would be
    8960             :                  * either hopelessly confusing or an even poorer
    8961             :                  * representation of what the plan is actually doing.
    8962             :                  */
    8963           6 :                 need_parens = (list_length(fstore->newvals) != 1);
    8964           6 :                 if (need_parens)
    8965           6 :                     appendStringInfoString(buf, "ROW(");
    8966           6 :                 get_rule_expr((Node *) fstore->newvals, context, showimplicit);
    8967           6 :                 if (need_parens)
    8968           6 :                     appendStringInfoChar(buf, ')');
    8969             :             }
    8970           6 :             break;
    8971             : 
    8972        2166 :         case T_RelabelType:

    8980             :                     /* don't show the implicit cast */

    9010             :                 }

    9078             :                 {

    9081             :                 }

    9085        1368 :                     Node       *w = (Node *) when->expr;

    9087        1368 :                     if (caseexpr->arg)
    9088             :                     {
    9089             :                         /*
    9090             :                          * The parser should have produced WHEN clauses of the
    9091             :                          * form "CaseTestExpr = RHS", possibly with an
    9092             :                          * implicit coercion inserted above the CaseTestExpr.
    9093             :                          * For accurate decompilation of rules it's essential
    9094             :                          * that we show just the RHS.  However in an
    9095             :                          * expression that's been through the optimizer, the
    9096             :                          * WHEN clause could be almost anything (since the
    9097             :                          * equality operator could have been expanded into an
    9098             :                          * inline function).  If we don't recognize the form
    9099             :                          * of the WHEN clause, just punt and display it as-is.
    9100             :                          */
    9101         512 :                         if (IsA(w, OpExpr))
    9102             :                         {
    9103         512 :                             List       *args = ((OpExpr *) w)->args;
    9104             :

    9106         512 :                                 IsA(strip_implicit_coercions(linitial(args)),
    9107             :                                     CaseTestExpr))
    9108         512 :                                 w = (Node *) lsecond(args);
    9109             :                         }
    9110             :                     }
    9111             : 
    9112        1368 :                     if (!PRETTY_INDENT(context))
    9113          82 :                         appendStringInfoChar(buf, ' ');

    9115             :                                          0, 0, 0);

    9498        2346 :         case T_NullTest:
    9499             :             {
    9500        2346 :                 NullTest   *ntest = (NullTest *) node;
    9501             : 
    9502        2346 :                 if (!PRETTY_PAREN(context))
    9503        2292 :                     appendStringInfoChar(buf, '(');
    9504        2346 :                 get_rule_expr_paren((Node *) ntest->arg, context, true, node);
    9505             : 
    9506             :                 /*
    9507             :                  * For scalar inputs, we prefer to print as IS [NOT] NULL,
    9508             :                  * which is shorter and traditional.  If it's a rowtype input
    9509             :                  * but we're applying a scalar test, must print IS [NOT]
    9510             :                  * DISTINCT FROM NULL to be semantically correct.
    9511             :                  */
    9512        2346 :                 if (ntest->argisrow ||
    9513        2316 :                     !type_is_rowtype(exprType((Node *) ntest->arg)))
    9514             :                 {
    9515        4656 :                     switch (ntest->nulltesttype)
    9516             :                     {
    9517         780 :                         case IS_NULL:
    9518         780 :                             appendStringInfoString(buf, " IS NULL");
    9519         780 :                             break;

    9822             : /*
    9823             :  * get_rule_expr_toplevel       - Parse back a toplevel expression
    9824             :  *
    9825             :  * Same as get_rule_expr(), except that if the expr is just a Var, we pass
    9826             :  * istoplevel = true not false to get_variable().  This causes whole-row Vars
    9827             :  * to get printed with decoration that will prevent expansion of "*".
    9828             :  * We need to use this in contexts such as ROW() and VALUES(), where the
    9829             :  * parser would expand "foo.*" appearing at top level.  (In principle we'd
    9830             :  * use this in get_target_list() too, but that has additional worries about
    9831             :  * whether to print AS, so it needs to invoke get_variable() directly anyway.)
    9832             :  */
    9833             : static void
    9834        2768 : get_rule_expr_toplevel(Node *node, deparse_context *context,
    9835             :                        bool showimplicit)
    9836             : {
    9837        2768 :     if (node && IsA(node, Var))
    9838        1070 :         (void) get_variable((Var *) node, 0, true, context);
    9839             :     else
    9840        1698 :         get_rule_expr(node, context, showimplicit);
    9841        2768 : }
    9842             : 
    9843             : /*
    9844             :  * get_rule_list_toplevel       - Parse back a list of toplevel expressions
    9845             :  *
    9846             :  * Apply get_rule_expr_toplevel() to each element of a List.
    9847             :  *
    9848             :  * This adds commas between the expressions, but caller is responsible
    9849             :  * for printing surrounding decoration.
    9850             :  */
    9851             : static void
    9852         396 : get_rule_list_toplevel(List *lst, deparse_context *context,

    9860             :     {
    9861         998 :         Node       *e = (Node *) lfirst(lc);
    9862             :

    9864         998 :         get_rule_expr_toplevel(e, context, showimplicit);

    9867         396 : }
    9868             : 
    9869             : /*
    9870             :  * get_rule_expr_funccall       - Parse back a function-call expression
    9871             :  *
    9872             :  * Same as get_rule_expr(), except that we guarantee that the output will
    9873             :  * look like a function call, or like one of the things the grammar treats as
    9874             :  * equivalent to a function call (see the func_expr_windowless production).
    9875             :  * This is needed in places where the grammar uses func_expr_windowless and
    9876             :  * you can't substitute a parenthesized a_expr.  If what we have isn't going
    9877             :  * to look like a function call, wrap it in a dummy CAST() expression, which
    9878             :  * will satisfy the grammar --- and, indeed, is likely what the user wrote to
    9879             :  * produce such a thing.
    9880             :  */
    9881             : static void
    9882         642 : get_rule_expr_funccall(Node *node, deparse_context *context,
    9883             :                        bool showimplicit)
    9884             : {
    9885         642 :     if (looks_like_function(node))
    9886         630 :         get_rule_expr(node, context, showimplicit);
    9887             :     else
    9888             :     {
    9889          12 :         StringInfo  buf = context->buf;
    9890             : 
    9891          12 :         appendStringInfoString(buf, "CAST(");
    9892             :         /* no point in showing any top-level implicit cast */
    9893          12 :         get_rule_expr(node, context, false);
    9894          12 :         appendStringInfo(buf, " AS %s)",
    9895             :                          format_type_with_typemod(exprType(node),
    9896             :                                                   exprTypmod(node)));
    9897             :     }
    9898         642 : }
    9899             : 
    9900             : /*
    9901             :  * Helper function to identify node types that satisfy func_expr_windowless.
    9902             :  * If in doubt, "false" is always a safe answer.
    9903             :  */
    9904             : static bool
    9905        1678 : looks_like_function(Node *node)
    9906             : {
    9907        1678 :     if (node == NULL)
    9908           0 :         return false;           /* probably shouldn't happen */
    9909        1678 :     switch (nodeTag(node))
    9910             :     {
    9911         670 :         case T_FuncExpr:
    9912             :             /* OK, unless it's going to deparse as a cast */
    9913         688 :             return (((FuncExpr *) node)->funcformat == COERCE_EXPLICIT_CALL ||
    9914          18 :                     ((FuncExpr *) node)->funcformat == COERCE_SQL_SYNTAX);
    9915         108 :         case T_NullIfExpr:
    9916             :         case T_CoalesceExpr:
    9917             :         case T_MinMaxExpr:
    9918             :         case T_SQLValueFunction:
    9919             :         case T_XmlExpr:
    9920             :             /* these are all accepted by func_expr_common_subexpr */
    9921         108 :             return true;
    9922         900 :         default:
    9923         900 :             break;
    9924             :     }
    9925         900 :     return false;
    9926             : }
    9927             :

    9969             : /*
    9970             :  * get_func_expr            - Parse back a FuncExpr node

    9972             : static void
    9973       10286 : get_func_expr(FuncExpr *expr, deparse_context *context,
    9974             :               bool showimplicit)
    9975             : {
    9976       10286 :     StringInfo  buf = context->buf;
    9977       10286 :     Oid         funcoid = expr->funcid;
    9978             :     Oid         argtypes[FUNC_MAX_ARGS];

    9980             :     List       *argnames;
    9981             :     bool        use_variadic;
    9982             :     ListCell   *l;
    9983             : 
    9984             :     /*
    9985             :      * If the function call came from an implicit coercion, then just show the
    9986             :      * first argument --- unless caller wants to see implicit coercions.
    9987             :      */
    9988       10286 :     if (expr->funcformat == COERCE_IMPLICIT_CAST && !showimplicit)
    9989             :     {
    9990        1068 :         get_rule_expr_paren((Node *) linitial(expr->args), context,
    9991             :                             false, (Node *) expr);
    9992        2650 :         return;
    9993             :     }
    9994             : 
    9995             :     /*
    9996             :      * If the function call came from a cast, then show the first argument
    9997             :      * plus an explicit cast operation.
    9998             :      */
    9999        9218 :     if (expr->funcformat == COERCE_EXPLICIT_CAST ||
   10000        8658 :         expr->funcformat == COERCE_IMPLICIT_CAST)
   10001             :     {
   10002        1408 :         Node       *arg = linitial(expr->args);
   10003        1408 :         Oid         rettype = expr->funcresulttype;
   10004             :         int32       coercedTypmod;
   10005             : 
   10006             :         /* Get the typmod if this is a length-coercion function */

   10008             : 
   10009        1408 :         get_coercion_expr(arg, context,
   10010             :                           rettype, coercedTypmod,
   10011             :                           (Node *) expr);
   10012             : 
   10013        1408 :         return;
   10014             :     }
   10015             : 
   10016             :     /*
   10017             :      * If the function was called using one of the SQL spec's random special
   10018             :      * syntaxes, try to reproduce that.  If we don't recognize the function,
   10019             :      * fall through.
   10020             :      */
   10021        7810 :     if (expr->funcformat == COERCE_SQL_SYNTAX)
   10022             :     {
   10023         180 :         if (get_func_sql_syntax(expr, context))
   10024         174 :             return;
   10025             :     }
   10026             : 
   10027             :     /*
   10028             :      * Normal function: display as proname(args).  First we need to extract
   10029             :      * the argument datatypes.
   10030             :      */
   10031        7636 :     if (list_length(expr->args) > FUNC_MAX_ARGS)
   10032           0 :         ereport(ERROR,
   10033             :                 (errcode(ERRCODE_TOO_MANY_ARGUMENTS),
   10034             :                  errmsg("too many arguments")));
   10035        7636 :     nargs = 0;
   10036        7636 :     argnames = NIL;
   10037       16182 :     foreach(l, expr->args)
   10038             :     {
   10039        8546 :         Node       *arg = (Node *) lfirst(l);
   10040             : 
   10041        8546 :         if (IsA(arg, NamedArgExpr))
   10042          18 :             argnames = lappend(argnames, ((NamedArgExpr *) arg)->name);
   10043        8546 :         argtypes[nargs] = exprType(arg);
   10044        8546 :         nargs++;
   10045             :     }
   10046             : 
   10047        7636 :     appendStringInfo(buf, "%s(",
   10048             :                      generate_function_name(funcoid, nargs,

   10572             : /* ----------
   10573             :  * get_coercion_expr
   10574             :  *
   10575             :  *  Make a string representation of a value coerced to a specific type
   10576             :  * ----------
   10577             :  */
   10578             : static void
   10579        4132 : get_coercion_expr(Node *arg, deparse_context *context,
   10580             :                   Oid resulttype, int32 resulttypmod,
   10581             :                   Node *parentNode)
   10582             : {
   10583        4132 :     StringInfo  buf = context->buf;
   10584             : 
   10585             :     /*
   10586             :      * Since parse_coerce.c doesn't immediately collapse application of
   10587             :      * length-coercion functions to constants, what we'll typically see in
   10588             :      * such cases is a Const with typmod -1 and a length-coercion function
   10589             :      * right above it.  Avoid generating redundant output. However, beware of
   10590             :      * suppressing casts when the user actually wrote something like
   10591             :      * 'foo'::text::char(3).
   10592             :      *
   10593             :      * Note: it might seem that we are missing the possibility of needing to
   10594             :      * print a COLLATE clause for such a Const.  However, a Const could only
   10595             :      * have nondefault collation in a post-constant-folding tree, in which the
   10596             :      * length coercion would have been folded too.  See also the special
   10597             :      * handling of CollateExpr in coerce_to_target_type(): any collation
   10598             :      * marking will be above the coercion node, not below it.
   10599             :      */
   10600        4132 :     if (arg && IsA(arg, Const) &&
   10601         468 :         ((Const *) arg)->consttype == resulttype &&
   10602          24 :         ((Const *) arg)->consttypmod == -1)
   10603             :     {
   10604             :         /* Show the constant without normal ::typename decoration */
   10605          24 :         get_const_expr((Const *) arg, context, -1);
   10606             :     }
   10607             :     else
   10608             :     {
   10609        4108 :         if (!PRETTY_PAREN(context))
   10610        3780 :             appendStringInfoChar(buf, '(');
   10611        4108 :         get_rule_expr_paren(arg, context, false, parentNode);
   10612        4108 :         if (!PRETTY_PAREN(context))
   10613        3780 :             appendStringInfoChar(buf, ')');
   10614             :     }
   10615             : 
   10616             :     /*
   10617             :      * Never emit resulttype(arg) functional notation. A pg_proc entry could
   10618             :      * take precedence, and a resulttype in pg_temp would require schema
   10619             :      * qualification that format_type_with_typemod() would usually omit. We've
   10620             :      * standardized on arg::resulttype, but CAST(arg AS resulttype) notation
   10621             :      * would work fine.
   10622             :      */
   10623        4132 :     appendStringInfo(buf, "::%s",
   10624             :                      format_type_with_typemod(resulttype, resulttypmod));
   10625        4132 : }
   10626             : 
   10627             : /* ----------
   10628             :  * get_const_expr
   10629             :  *
   10630             :  *  Make a string representation of a Const
   10631             :  *
   10632             :  * showtype can be -1 to never show "::typename" decoration, or +1 to always
   10633             :  * show it, or 0 to show it only if the constant wouldn't be assumed to be
   10634             :  * the right type by default.
   10635             :  *
   10636             :  * If the Const's collation isn't default for its type, show that too.
   10637             :  * We mustn't do this when showtype is -1 (since that means the caller will
   10638             :  * print "::typename", and we can't put a COLLATE clause in between).  It's
   10639             :  * caller's responsibility that collation isn't missed in such cases.
   10640             :  * ----------
   10641             :  */
   10642             : static void
   10643       59808 : get_const_expr(Const *constval, deparse_context *context, int showtype)
   10644             : {
   10645       59808 :     StringInfo  buf = context->buf;

   10652             :     {
   10653             :         /*
   10654             :          * Always label the type of a NULL constant to prevent misdecisions
   10655             :          * about type when reparsing.
   10656             :          */
   10657         830 :         appendStringInfoString(buf, "NULL");
   10658         830 :         if (showtype >= 0)
   10659             :         {

   10677             :             /*
   10678             :              * INT4 can be printed without any decoration, unless it is
   10679             :              * negative; in that case print it as '-nnn'::integer to ensure
   10680             :              * that the output will re-parse as a constant, not as a constant
   10681             :              * plus operator.  In most cases we could get away with printing
   10682             :              * (-nnn) instead, because of the way that gram.y handles negative

   10695        1060 :         case NUMERICOID:

   10955             : /*
   10956             :  * simple_quote_literal - Format a string as a SQL literal, append to buf
   10957             :  */
   10958             : static void
   10959       23806 : simple_quote_literal(StringInfo buf, const char *val)
   10960             : {
   10961             :     const char *valptr;
   10962             : 
   10963             :     /*
   10964             :      * We form the string literal according to the prevailing setting of
   10965             :      * standard_conforming_strings; we never use E''. User is responsible for
   10966             :      * making sure result is used correctly.
   10967             :      */
   10968       23806 :     appendStringInfoChar(buf, '\'');
   10969      245112 :     for (valptr = val; *valptr; valptr++)
   10970             :     {
   10971      221306 :         char        ch = *valptr;
   10972             : 
   10973      221306 :         if (SQL_STR_DOUBLE(ch, !standard_conforming_strings))
   10974         306 :             appendStringInfoChar(buf, ch);
   10975      221306 :         appendStringInfoChar(buf, ch);
   10976             :     }
   10977       23806 :     appendStringInfoChar(buf, '\'');
   10978       23806 : }

   10981             : /* ----------
   10982             :  * get_sublink_expr         - Parse back a sublink
   10983             :  * ----------
   10984             :  */
   10985             : static void
   10986         406 : get_sublink_expr(SubLink *sublink, deparse_context *context)
   10987             : {
   10988         406 :     StringInfo  buf = context->buf;
   10989         406 :     Query      *query = (Query *) (sublink->subselect);
   10990         406 :     char       *opname = NULL;
   10991             :     bool        need_paren;
   10992             : 
   10993         406 :     if (sublink->subLinkType == ARRAY_SUBLINK)
   10994          16 :         appendStringInfoString(buf, "ARRAY(");
   10995             :     else
   10996         390 :         appendStringInfoChar(buf, '(');
   10997             : 
   10998             :     /*
   10999             :      * Note that we print the name of only the first operator, when there are
   11000             :      * multiple combining operators.  This is an approximation that could go
   11001             :      * wrong in various scenarios (operators in different schemas, renamed
   11002             :      * operators, etc) but there is not a whole lot we can do about it, since
   11003             :      * the syntax allows only one operator to be shown.
   11004             :      */
   11005         406 :     if (sublink->testexpr)
   11006             :     {
   11007          18 :         if (IsA(sublink->testexpr, OpExpr))
   11008             :         {
   11009             :             /* single combining operator */
   11010           6 :             OpExpr     *opexpr = (OpExpr *) sublink->testexpr;
   11011             : 
   11012           6 :             get_rule_expr(linitial(opexpr->args), context, true);
   11013           6 :             opname = generate_operator_name(opexpr->opno,
   11014           6 :                                             exprType(linitial(opexpr->args)),
   11015           6 :                                             exprType(lsecond(opexpr->args)));
   11016             :         }
   11017          12 :         else if (IsA(sublink->testexpr, BoolExpr))
   11018             :         {
   11019             :             /* multiple combining operators, = or <> cases */
   11020             :             char       *sep;
   11021             :             ListCell   *l;
   11022             : 
   11023           6 :             appendStringInfoChar(buf, '(');
   11024           6 :             sep = "";

   11026             :             {
   11027          12 :                 OpExpr     *opexpr = lfirst_node(OpExpr, l);
   11028             : 
   11029          12 :                 appendStringInfoString(buf, sep);
   11030          12 :                 get_rule_expr(linitial(opexpr->args), context, true);
   11031          12 :                 if (!opname)
   11032           6 :                     opname = generate_operator_name(opexpr->opno,
   11033           6 :                                                     exprType(linitial(opexpr->args)),
   11034           6 :                                                     exprType(lsecond(opexpr->args)));
   11035          12 :                 sep = ", ";
   11036             :             }
   11037           6 :             appendStringInfoChar(buf, ')');
   11038             :         }

   11040             :         {

   11207             : /* ----------
   11208             :  * get_from_clause          - Parse back a FROM clause
   11209             :  *
   11210             :  * "prefix" is the keyword that denotes the start of the list of FROM
   11211             :  * elements. It is FROM when used to parse back SELECT and UPDATE, but
   11212             :  * is USING when parsing back DELETE.
   11213             :  * ----------
   11214             :  */
   11215             : static void
   11216        4078 : get_from_clause(Query *query, const char *prefix, deparse_context *context)
   11217             : {
   11218        4078 :     StringInfo  buf = context->buf;
   11219        4078 :     bool        first = true;
   11220             :     ListCell   *l;
   11221             : 
   11222             :     /*
   11223             :      * We use the query's jointree as a guide to what to print.  However, we
   11224             :      * must ignore auto-added RTEs that are marked not inFromCl. (These can
   11225             :      * only appear at the top level of the jointree, so it's sufficient to
   11226             :      * check here.)  This check also ensures we ignore the rule pseudo-RTEs
   11227             :      * for NEW and OLD.
   11228             :      */
   11229        8136 :     foreach(l, query->jointree->fromlist)
   11230             :     {
   11231        4058 :         Node       *jtnode = (Node *) lfirst(l);

   11233        4058 :         if (IsA(jtnode, RangeTblRef))

   11237             : 
   11238        3290 :             if (!rte->inFromCl)
   11239         372 :                 continue;
   11240             :         }
   11241             : 
   11242        3686 :         if (first)
   11243             :         {
   11244        3374 :             appendContextKeyword(context, prefix,
   11245             :                                  -PRETTYINDENT_STD, PRETTYINDENT_STD, 2);
   11246        3374 :             first = false;
   11247             : 
   11248        3374 :             get_from_clause_item(jtnode, query, context);
   11249             :         }
   11250             :         else
   11251             :         {
   11252             :             StringInfoData itembuf;
   11253             : 
   11254         312 :             appendStringInfoString(buf, ", ");
   11255             : 
   11256             :             /*
   11257             :              * Put the new FROM item's text into itembuf so we can decide
   11258             :              * after we've got it whether or not it needs to go on a new line.
   11259             :              */

   11261         312 :             context->buf = &itembuf;
   11262             : 
   11263         312 :             get_from_clause_item(jtnode, query, context);
   11264             : 
   11265             :             /* Restore context's output buffer */
   11266         312 :             context->buf = buf;
   11267             : 
   11268             :             /* Consider line-wrapping if enabled */

   11271             :                 /* Does the new item start with a new line? */

   11855             : /*
   11856             :  * processIndirection - take care of array and subfield assignment
   11857             :  *
   11858             :  * We strip any top-level FieldStore or assignment SubscriptingRef nodes that
   11859             :  * appear in the input, printing them as decoration for the base column
   11860             :  * name (which we assume the caller just printed).  We might also need to
   11861             :  * strip CoerceToDomain nodes, but only ones that appear above assignment
   11862             :  * nodes.
   11863             :  *
   11864             :  * Returns the subexpression that's to be assigned.

   11967             : 
   11968             : /*
   11969             :  * quote_identifier         - Quote an identifier only if needed
   11970             :  *
   11971             :  * When quotes are needed, we palloc the required space; slightly
   11972             :  * space-wasteful but well worth it for notational simplicity.
   11973             :  */
   11974             : const char *
   11975     2226578 : quote_identifier(const char *ident)
   11976             : {
   11977             :     /*
   11978             :      * Can avoid quoting if ident starts with a lowercase letter or underscore
   11979             :      * and contains only lowercase letters, digits, and underscores, *and* is
   11980             :      * not any SQL keyword.  Otherwise, supply quotes.
   11981             :      */
   11982     2226578 :     int         nquotes = 0;
   11983             :     bool        safe;
   11984             :     const char *ptr;
   11985             :     char       *result;
   11986             :     char       *optr;
   11987             : 
   11988             :     /*
   11989             :      * would like to use <ctype.h> macros here, but they might yield unwanted
   11990             :      * locale-specific results...
   11991             :      */
   11992     2226578 :     safe = ((ident[0] >= 'a' && ident[0] <= 'z') || ident[0] == '_');
   11993             : 
   11994    18572444 :     for (ptr = ident; *ptr; ptr++)
   11995             :     {
   11996    16345866 :         char        ch = *ptr;
   11997             : 
   11998    16345866 :         if ((ch >= 'a' && ch <= 'z') ||
   11999     1934048 :             (ch >= '0' && ch <= '9') ||
   12000             :             (ch == '_'))
   12001             :         {
   12002             :             /* okay */
   12003             :         }
   12004             :         else
   12005             :         {
   12006       58796 :             safe = false;
   12007       58796 :             if (ch == '"')
   12008          12 :                 nquotes++;
   12009             :         }
   12010             :     }
   12011             : 
   12012     2226578 :     if (quote_all_identifiers)
   12013       11188 :         safe = false;
   12014             : 
   12015     2226578 :     if (safe)
   12016             :     {
   12017             :         /*
   12018             :          * Check for keyword.  We quote keywords except for unreserved ones.
   12019             :          * (In some cases we could avoid quoting a col_name or type_func_name
   12020             :          * keyword, but it seems much harder than it's worth to tell that.)
   12021             :          *
   12022             :          * Note: ScanKeywordLookup() does case-insensitive comparison, but
   12023             :          * that's fine, since we already know we have all-lower-case.
   12024             :          */
   12025     2191218 :         int         kwnum = ScanKeywordLookup(ident, &ScanKeywords);
   12026             : 
   12027     2191218 :         if (kwnum >= 0 && ScanKeywordCategories[kwnum] != UNRESERVED_KEYWORD)
   12028        2348 :             safe = false;
   12029             :     }
   12030             : 
   12031     2226578 :     if (safe)
   12032     2188870 :         return ident;           /* no change needed */
   12033             : 
   12034       37708 :     result = (char *) palloc(strlen(ident) + nquotes + 2 + 1);
   12035             : 
   12036       37708 :     optr = result;
   12037       37708 :     *optr++ = '"';
   12038      217866 :     for (ptr = ident; *ptr; ptr++)
   12039             :     {
   12040      180158 :         char        ch = *ptr;
   12041             : 
   12042      180158 :         if (ch == '"')
   12043          12 :             *optr++ = '"';
   12044      180158 :         *optr++ = ch;
   12045             :     }
   12046       37708 :     *optr++ = '"';
   12047       37708 :     *optr = '\0';
   12048             : 
   12049       37708 :     return result;
   12050             : }
   12051             : 
   12052             : /*
   12053             :  * quote_qualified_identifier   - Quote a possibly-qualified identifier
   12054             :  *
   12055             :  * Return a name of the form qualifier.ident, or just ident if qualifier
   12056             :  * is NULL, quoting each component if necessary.  The result is palloc'd.
   12057             :  */
   12058             : char *
   12059     1064552 : quote_qualified_identifier(const char *qualifier,
   12060             :                            const char *ident)
   12061             : {

   12185             : /*
   12186             :  * generate_function_name
   12187             :  *      Compute the name to display for a function specified by OID,
   12188             :  *      given that it is being called with the specified actual arg names and
   12189             :  *      types.  (Those matter because of ambiguous-function resolution rules.)
   12190             :  *
   12191             :  * If we're dealing with a potentially variadic function (in practice, this
   12192             :  * means a FuncExpr or Aggref, not some other way of calling a function), then
   12193             :  * has_variadic must specify whether variadic arguments have been merged,
   12194             :  * and *use_variadic_p will be set to indicate whether to print VARIADIC in
   12195             :  * the output.  For non-FuncExpr cases, has_variadic should be false and
   12196             :  * use_variadic_p can be NULL.
   12197             :  *
   12198             :  * The result includes all necessary quoting and schema-prefixing.
   12199             :  */
   12200             : static char *
   12201       10758 : generate_function_name(Oid funcid, int nargs, List *argnames, Oid *argtypes,

   12210             :     char       *nspname;
   12211             :     FuncDetailCode p_result;
   12212             :     Oid         p_funcid;
   12213             :     Oid         p_rettype;
   12214             :     bool        p_retset;
   12215             :     int         p_nvargs;

   12224       10758 :     proname = NameStr(procform->proname);
   12225             :

   12228             :      * qualification in some special cases.
   12229             :      */

   12231             :     {
   12232           0 :         if (strcmp(proname, "cube") == 0 || strcmp(proname, "rollup") == 0)

   12235             : 
   12236             :     /*
   12237             :      * Determine whether VARIADIC should be printed.  We must do this first

   12240             :      * We always print VARIADIC if the function has a merged variadic-array

   12242             :      * VARIADIC argument type other than VARIADIC ANY.  If we omitted VARIADIC

   12244             :      * match a newer non-VARIADIC function.

   12257             :     }

   12259             :     /*

   12269       10758 :                                    !use_variadic, true, false,

   12272       10758 :                                    &p_true_typeids, NULL);
   12273             :     else
   12274             :     {

   12294             : /*
   12295             :  * generate_operator_name

   12298             :  *      (Arg types matter because of ambiguous-operator resolution rules.
   12299             :  *      Pass InvalidOid for unused arg of a unary operator.)
   12300             :  *

   12364             : 
   12365             : /*
   12366             :  * generate_operator_clause --- generate a binary-operator WHERE clause
   12367             :  *
   12368             :  * This is used for internally-generated-and-executed SQL queries, where
   12369             :  * precision is essential and readability is secondary.  The basic
   12370             :  * requirement is to append "leftop op rightop" to buf, where leftop and
   12371             :  * rightop are given as strings and are assumed to yield types leftoptype
   12372             :  * and rightoptype; the operator is identified by OID.  The complexity
   12373             :  * comes from needing to be sure that the parser will select the desired
   12374             :  * operator when the query is parsed.  We always name the operator using
   12375             :  * OPERATOR(schema.op) syntax, so as to avoid search-path uncertainties.
   12376             :  * We have to emit casts too, if either input isn't already the input type
   12377             :  * of the operator; else we are at the mercy of the parser's heuristics for
   12378             :  * ambiguous-operator resolution.  The caller must ensure that leftop and
   12379             :  * rightop are suitable arguments for a cast operation; it's best to insert
   12380             :  * parentheses if they aren't just variables or parameters.
   12381             :  */
   12382             : void
   12383        5042 : generate_operator_clause(StringInfo buf,
   12384             :                          const char *leftop, Oid leftoptype,
   12385             :                          Oid opoid,
   12386             :                          const char *rightop, Oid rightoptype)
   12387             : {
   12388             :     HeapTuple   opertup;
   12389             :     Form_pg_operator operform;
   12390             :     char       *oprname;
   12391             :     char       *nspname;
   12392             : 
   12393        5042 :     opertup = SearchSysCache1(OPEROID, ObjectIdGetDatum(opoid));
   12394        5042 :     if (!HeapTupleIsValid(opertup))
   12395           0 :         elog(ERROR, "cache lookup failed for operator %u", opoid);
   12396        5042 :     operform = (Form_pg_operator) GETSTRUCT(opertup);
   12397        5042 :     Assert(operform->oprkind == 'b');
   12398        5042 :     oprname = NameStr(operform->oprname);
   12399             : 
   12400        5042 :     nspname = get_namespace_name(operform->oprnamespace);
   12401             : 
   12402        5042 :     appendStringInfoString(buf, leftop);
   12403        5042 :     if (leftoptype != operform->oprleft)
   12404          42 :         add_cast_to(buf, operform->oprleft);
   12405        5042 :     appendStringInfo(buf, " OPERATOR(%s.", quote_identifier(nspname));
   12406        5042 :     appendStringInfoString(buf, oprname);
   12407        5042 :     appendStringInfo(buf, ") %s", rightop);
   12408        5042 :     if (rightoptype != operform->oprright)
   12409          60 :         add_cast_to(buf, operform->oprright);
   12410             : 
   12411        5042 :     ReleaseSysCache(opertup);
   12412        5042 : }
   12413             : 
   12414             : /*
   12415             :  * Add a cast specification to buf.  We spell out the type name the hard way,
   12416             :  * intentionally not using format_type_be().  This is to avoid corner cases
   12417             :  * for CHARACTER, BIT, and perhaps other types, where specifying the type
   12418             :  * using SQL-standard syntax results in undesirable data truncation.  By
   12419             :  * doing it this way we can be certain that the cast will have default (-1)
   12420             :  * target typmod.
   12421             :  */
   12422             : static void

   12432           0 :         elog(ERROR, "cache lookup failed for type %u", typid);
   12433         102 :     typform = (Form_pg_type) GETSTRUCT(typetup);
   12434             :

   12528             : /*
   12529             :  * Generate a C string representing a relation options from text[] datum.
   12530             :  */
   12531             : static void
   12532         240 : get_reloptions(StringInfo buf, Datum reloptions)
   12533             : {
   12534             :     Datum      *options;
   12535             :     int         noptions;
   12536             :     int         i;
   12537             : 
   12538         240 :     deconstruct_array_builtin(DatumGetArrayTypeP(reloptions), TEXTOID,
   12539             :                               &options, NULL, &noptions);
   12540             : 
   12541         500 :     for (i = 0; i < noptions; i++)
   12542             :     {
   12543         260 :         char       *option = TextDatumGetCString(options[i]);
   12544             :         char       *name;
   12545             :         char       *separator;
   12546             :         char       *value;
   12547             : 
   12548             :         /*
   12549             :          * Each array element should have the form name=value.  If the "=" is
   12550             :          * missing for some reason, treat it like an empty value.
   12551             :          */
   12552         260 :         name = option;
   12553         260 :         separator = strchr(option, '=');
   12554         260 :         if (separator)
   12555             :         {
   12556         260 :             *separator = '\0';
   12557         260 :             value = separator + 1;
   12558             :         }
   12559             :         else
   12560           0 :             value = "";
   12561             : 
   12562         260 :         if (i > 0)
   12563          20 :             appendStringInfoString(buf, ", ");
   12564         260 :         appendStringInfo(buf, "%s=", quote_identifier(name));
   12565             : 
   12566             :         /*
   12567             :          * In general we need to quote the value; but to avoid unnecessary
   12568             :          * clutter, do not quote if it is an identifier that would not need
   12569             :          * quoting.  (We could also allow numbers, but that is a bit trickier
   12570             :          * than it looks --- for example, are leading zeroes significant?  We
   12571             :          * don't want to assume very much here about what custom reloptions
   12572             :          * might mean.)
   12573             :          */
   12574         260 :         if (quote_identifier(value) == value)
   12575           8 :             appendStringInfoString(buf, value);
   12576             :         else
   12577         252 :             simple_quote_literal(buf, value);
   12578             : 
   12579         260 :         pfree(option);
   12580             :     }
   12581         240 : }
   12582             : 
   12583             : /*
   12584             :  * Generate a C string representing a relation's reloptions, or NULL if none.
   12585             :  */
   12586             : static char *
   12587        6378 : flatten_reloptions(Oid relid)
   12588             : {
   12589        6378 :     char       *result = NULL;
   12590             :     HeapTuple   tuple;
   12591             :     Datum       reloptions;
   12592             :     bool        isnull;
   12593             : 
   12594        6378 :     tuple = SearchSysCache1(RELOID, ObjectIdGetDatum(relid));
   12595        6378 :     if (!HeapTupleIsValid(tuple))
   12596           0 :         elog(ERROR, "cache lookup failed for relation %u", relid);
   12597             : 
   12598        6378 :     reloptions = SysCacheGetAttr(RELOID, tuple,
   12599             :                                  Anum_pg_class_reloptions, &isnull);
   12600        6378 :     if (!isnull)
   12601             :     {
   12602             :         StringInfoData buf;
   12603             : 
   12604         210 :         initStringInfo(&buf);
   12605         210 :         get_reloptions(&buf, reloptions);
   12606             : 
   12607         210 :         result = buf.data;
   12608             :     }
   12609             : 
   12610        6378 :     ReleaseSysCache(tuple);
   12611             : 
   12612        6378 :     return result;
   12613             : }

   12615             : /*
   12616             :  * get_range_partbound_string
   12617             :  *      A C string representation of one range partition bound

   12619             : char *
   12620        4224 : get_range_partbound_string(List *bound_datums)
   12621             : {
   12622             :     deparse_context context;

   12631        4224 :     sep = "";
